facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2727 of 1972 filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 2727 of 1972.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated August 17, 1972 of Punjab and Haryana High Court in Election Petition 45 of 1972.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 17, 1972 of the Punjab and Haryana High Court in Election Petition 45 of 1972.

facts.text: Election to Haryana Vidhan Sabha from Jhajjar constituency held on 11-3-1973.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal arises out of the election to the, Haryana Vidhan Sabha from the Jhajjar companystituency held on 11-3-1973 in which the appellant was declared elected on receiving 24060 votes as against 23975 votes received by the respondent.

facts.text: Appellant declared elected receiving 24060 votes against 23975 votes received by respondent.

anchor.surface_text: in which the appellant was declared elected on receiving 24060 votes as against 23975 votes received by the respondent. The respondent thereupon filed the petition challenging the validity of the election.

facts.text: Respondent filed election petition challenging validity of the election.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent thereupon filed the petition challenging the validity of the election. The appeal itself is against the order dated 17th August 1972 passed by- the learned Single Judge of the High Court,

facts.text: High Court Single Judge passed order dated 17th August 1972 on issues 1,2,3,4,5,6,7a and 7b of election petition.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal itself is against the order dated 17th August 1972 passed by- the learned Single Judge of the High Court, who heard the election petition in respect of issues 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7  a  and 7 b  Issue 2 itself was number challenged before this, Court.

facts.text: Election petitioner alleged respondent got 28 votes of dead voters at specified booths.

anchor.surface_text: Para 9 ii  That the respondent got 28 votes of the dead voters polled at Chhapa Booth No. 19, Machhrauli Booth No. 31, Silani Booths No. 38 and 39, Silani Pans Zalim Booth No. 40, Silani Panna Keso Booth No. 41, Bhadani Booth No. 56, Chhudani Booth No. 58, Sheikhupura Jat Booth No. 61 and Badli Booth No. 79.

facts.text: Election petitioner alleged 710 votes of absent, missing, sick, convicts, deserted ladies impersonated by friends and relations of respondent.

anchor.surface_text: That a large number of voters, who were either absentees or missing or sick in hospitals or companyvicts lodged in jail and deserted ladies have been impersonated by the friends and relations of the respondent for whom they have all polled and their total number is 710.

facts.text: Election petitioner alleged 158 Government servants not present in villages but impersonated and votes polled for respondent.

anchor.surface_text: That a large number of Government servants numbering 158 who were number present in their respective villages and did number cast their votes in fact, have been impersonated and their votes have been polled in favour of the respondent.

facts.text: Election petitioner alleged votes of same persons registered in two or more places and polled multiple times for respondent.

anchor.surface_text: That the respondent got the same votes registered in two or more different places in Haryana Assembly Jhajjar Constituency No. 44- The said persons are near or distant relations or friends of the respondent. The said voters polled their votes at two different places in the same companystituency and in other companystituencies i.e.

facts.text: About 149 persons alleged to have voted twice or more by election petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: Issue  5  relates to the case of about 149 persons who were said to have voted twice and in some cases more than twice either in the same companystituency or in more than one companystituency.

facts.text: Appellant denied all allegations and filed recrimination petition alleging same against petitioner for about 2200 votes.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant denied all the allegations made in these Paragraphs but he also filed a recrimination petition making the same allegations against the appellant in respect of about 2200 votes.

facts.text: Five schedules attached to election petition detailing dead voters, absent voters, govt servants, multiple voters.

anchor.surface_text: Five schedules were attached to the election petition. Schedule I gives the names and various details of all the 28 persons alleged to have been dead in whose name others were alleged to have voted. The dates on which they died were also given except in four cases.

facts.text: No polling took place at polling station No. 28 in village Bhatera despite 568 registered voters due to threats.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of this the entire village did number poll even a single vote on the day of polling at polling station No. 28 at village Bhatera.

facts.text: Respondent visited village Bhatera on or about 20-2-72 and threats made by Thakur Mohinder Singh to Harijan and backward voters.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent had visited village Bhatera a week before in Holi festival on or about 20-2-72 and approached Thakur Mohinder Singh to help him in securing the votes of village Bhatera.

facts.text: Counting of ballot papers started on 12-3-72 at 6.30 p.m. and continued till 2.50 A.M. on 13-3-72.

anchor.surface_text: That the companynting of the ballot papers started an 12-3-72 at 6.30 p.m. There were 12 tables in the room on Which there were companynting Assistants and the Supervisor on each table and each candidate had one companynting agent on each table.

facts.text: Petitioner alleged irregularities in counting at several tables, bundles not properly made, votes misallocated.

anchor.surface_text: During the companyrse of companynting the companynting agents of the petitioner several times objected that on tables 2, 3, 4, 5, 10 and 12, the Counting Assistants and Supervisors were number properly bundling the votes for the candidates.

facts.text: 1100 witnesses cited by respondent (election petitioner).

anchor.surface_text: He was particularly alarmed by the fact that the respondent had cited as many as 1100 witnesses whom he sought to examine in respect of various allegations made in the petition and the issues arising out of them.

facts.text: Rs. 60,000 deposited in court for summoning witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that about 1100 witnesses have been summoned and a sum of Rs. 60.000/- his been deported ,in the Court for the purpose of summoning these witnesses.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal and ordered appellant to pay respondent's costs.

anchor.surface_text: There is numbersubstance in any of the companytentions of the appellant and the appeal is, therefore, dismissed. The appellant will pay the respondents companyts.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 17, 1972 of the Punjab and Haryana High Court in Election Petition 45 of 1972.

issues.text: Whether issues 1, 3, 4 and 5 relating to impersonation of dead voters, absent voters, government servants and double/multiple voting should have been allowed to be raised given the particulars in the election petition

anchor.surface_text: The main contention of Mr. Garg, who appeared on behalf of the appellant, was that these issues should number have been allowed to be raised as the election petition did number companytain enough material particulars, that what was asked for was in the nature of a roving and fishing inquiry and should number be allowed. He was particularly alarmed by the fact that the respondent had cited as many as 1100 witnesses whom he sought to examine in respect of various allegations made in the petition and the issues arising out of them. We shall first of all deal with issues 1, 3, 4 and 5.

issues.text: Whether challenges to impersonated votes must be made by polling agents at the time of polling under Rule 36 of the Conduct of Election Rules, 1961

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Garg first took the extreme position that in respect of all these thousand and odd votes numberchallenge could be made in the election petition unless the respondents polling agents had challenged them at the time of the potting relying upon Rule 36 of the Conduct of Election Rules, 1961 which has made provision for challenges at the time of polling.

issues.text: Whether the election petition must specify the exact persons who impersonated dead or absent voters

anchor.surface_text: As we have already indicated, the election petition gives more particulars than would have been found by any body with any amount of experience in respect of election petitions Mr. Garg then went on to argue that where it is alleged that votes have been cast in the name of dead or absent persons it should be specifically stated who exactly voted in place of the dead or absent persons.

issues.text: Whether the election petition under section 83(1)(a) RPA must contain evidence in addition to material facts, analogous to Order VI Rule 2 CPC

anchor.surface_text: provisions of Order VI, Rule 2 of the Code of Civil Procedure, which provides that Every pleading shall contain, and contain only, a statement in a concise form of the material facts on which the party pleading relies for his claim or defence, as the case may be, but not the evidence by which they are to be proved The earlier part of the Rule, it would be noticed, is similar to clause 1 a of section 83.

issues.text: Whether issue 6 relating to corrupt practice of undue influence in village Bhatera has full particulars under section 83(1)(b) RPA

anchor.surface_text: As regards issue- 6 which relates to a corrupt practice, naturally particulars would have to be given as required under clause 1 b of section 83. In order to see whether the requirements of s. 83 1 b of giving full particulars of corrupt practices alleged by the respondent, including as full a statement as possible of the names of the parties alleged to have committed such corrupt practices, and the date and place of the commission of each such practice, have been met

issues.text: Whether issues 7(a) and 7(b) relating to irregularities and illegalities in the counting of votes raise triable issues

anchor.surface_text: As regards issues 7 a and 7 b , which relate to the irregularities committed during the course of the counting... The respondent totally repudiated these allegations and they also therefore give rise directly to issues 7 a , b and c as rightly held by, the learned High Court Judge. It is to be remembered that in this case we are still at the stage of pleadings and not at the stage of proof.

issues.text: Whether the prayer for inspection of ballot papers and counterfoils violates the secrecy of the ballot

anchor.surface_text: It has also to be noted that the, petitioner does not ask for a blanket order for opening of the ballot boxes or looking into all the counterfoils and thus seek to violate the secrecy of the ballot papers.

holdings.text: The election petition contains a concise statement of material facts as required under section 83(1)(a) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, with elaborate details in five schedules, sufficient for issues 1, 3, 4 and 5 relating to impersonation allegations.

anchor.surface_text: Under section 83 1  a  of the Representation of the People Act 1951, an election petition shall contain a concise statement of the material facts on which the petitioner relies. Under clause  b  it shall set forth AM particulars of any corrupt practice that the petitioner alleges, including as full a statement as possible of the names of the parties alleged to have committed such corrupt practice and the date and place of the commission of each such practice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petition provides names, booth numbers, dates of death, reasons for absence, death certificates; exceeds requirements for material facts, not evidence.

holdings.text: Challenges to impersonated votes need not be made by polling agents at the time of polling under Rule 36 of the Conduct of Election Rules, 1961; subsequent enquiries suffice if alleged within limitation period.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Garg first took the extreme position that in respect of all these thousand and odd votes no challenge could be made in the election petition unless the respondents polling agents had challenged them at the time of the polling relying upon Rule 36 of the Conduct of Election Rules, 1961 which has made provision for challenges at the time of polling.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Candidates may lack agents at all booths or local knowledge; law allows post-poll allegations based on later enquiries.

holdings.text: Election petition alleging impersonation of dead or absent voters need not specifically state the exact impersonators.

anchor.surface_text: As we have already indicated, the election petition gives more particulars than would have been found by any body with any amount of experience in respect of election petitions Mr. Garg then went on to argue that where it is alleged that votes have been cast in the name of dead or absent persons it should be specifically stated who exactly voted in place of the dead or absent persons.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.83(1)(a) requires only material facts, not evidence of impersonators; proof comes at trial via voters or counterfoils.

holdings.text: Election petitions, like CPC pleadings under Order VI Rule 2, must contain only material facts in concise form, not the evidence by which they are proved.

anchor.surface_text: provisions of Order VI, Rule 2 of the Code of Civil Procedure, which provides that Every pleading shall contain, and contain only, a statement in a concise form of the material facts on which the party pleading relies for his claim or defence, as the case may be, but not the evidence by which they are to be proved

holdings.reasoning_summary: Directly mirrors s.83(1)(a); CPC applies to election trials; evidence at trial, not pleadings.

holdings.text: Issue 6 on corrupt practice of undue influence contains full particulars under s.83(1)(b) RPA, including names, dates, places, giving rise to triable issue.

anchor.surface_text: As regards issue-  6  which relates to a corrupt practice, naturally particulars would have to be given as required under clause  1  b  of section 83. In order to see whether the requirements of s. 83 1   b  of giving full particulars of corrupt practices alleged by the respondent, including as full a statement as possible of the names of the parties alleged to have committed such corrupt practices,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Paras 13-14 detail respondent's visit ~20-2-72, names like Thakur Mohinder Singh, specific threats to named voters; disputed, thus triable.

holdings.text: Issues 7(a) and 7(b) on irregularities in counting raise triable issues at pleadings stage, despite repudiation.

anchor.surface_text: As regards issues 7 a  and 7 b , which relate to the irregularities committed during the course of the counting... The respondent totally repudiated these allegations and they also therefore give rise directly to issues 7 a ,  b  and  c  as rightly held by, the learned High Court Judge.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Detailed paras 27-31 allege specific tables, bundling errors, rejections; pleadings stage, not proof; repudiation creates issues.

holdings.text: Prayer for targeted inspection of ballot papers and counterfoils after proving impersonation does not violate secrecy of ballot.

anchor.surface_text: It has also to be noted that the, petitioner does not ask for a blanket order for opening of the ballot boxes or looking into all the counterfoils and thus seek to violate the secrecy of the ballot papers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Limited to genuine voters' counterfoils post-proof of non-voting; reasonable, not blanket.

holdings.text: The High Court Single Judge was right in allowing trial on issues 1, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7a and 7b; appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that the learned Judge was right in his conclusions with regard to these issues.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative rejection of appellant's contentions on insufficiency of particulars and roving inquiry.

holdings.text: Charges of corrupt practices under s.123 RPA are quasi-criminal and must be proved satisfactorily due to dual consequences of election set aside and disqualification.

anchor.surface_text: It has been held by this Court that charges of corrupt practices under s. 123 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 are quasi-criminal in nature, and should, therefore, be proved satisfactorily as it has a double consequence,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent application; to be borne in mind at proof stage.

Section 123 Representation of the People Act, 1951 support

anchor.surface_text: Under section 83 1  a  of the Representation of the People Act 1951, an election petition shall contain a concise statement of the material facts on which the petitioner relies. Under clause  b  it shall set forth AM particulars of any corrupt practice that the petitioner alleges, including as full a statement as possible of the names of the parties alleged to have committed such corrupt practice and the date and place of the commission of each such practice.
